scales_c_major.title: Major Scales
scales_c_major.description:
Start on C, then walk up the C Major Scale until you hit the octave note. Then go back down until you hit the root note. Repeat.

Once comfortable with this, try starting from different notes, walking up in the same pattern.

scales_natural_minor.title: Natural Minor Scales
scales_natural_minor.description: Walk up the Natural Minor Scale across three octaves. When you hit the top note, go back down until you hit the root note. Repeat. Do this in a variety of keys.

scales_harmonic_minor.title: Harmonic Minor Scales
scales_harmonic_minor.description: Walk up the Harmonic Minor Scale across three octaves. When you hit the top note, go back down until you hit the root note. Repeat. Do this in a variety of keys.

scales_chromatic.title: Chromatic Scale
scales_chromatic.description: Walk up the Chromatic Scale across the entire keyboard. When you hit the top note, go back down until you hit the bottom note. Repeat.

alternating_bass_4/4_in_c_major.title: Alternating Bass 4/4 in C Major
alternating_bass_4/4_in_c_major.description:
Practice playing a 4/4 Alternating Bass. Play the dimpled C bass note, then the C chord note, the G bass note, the C chord note, repeat.

Make sure to start slow and build speed as you improve. Remember, it's better to play slowly than poorly!

Once comfortable, do this exercise to a metronome to ensure you get the timing correct.

alternating_bass_4/4.title: Alternating Bass 4/4
alternating_bass_4/4.description: Practice playing a 4/4 Alternating Bass. Do this in a variety of different keys on both ends of the stradella keyboard so that you build muscle memory for all left-hand positions.

alternating_bass_4/4_minor.title: Alternating Bass 4/4 Minor
alternating_bass_4/4_minor.description: Practice playing a 4/4 Alternating Bass. Do this in a variety of different keys on both ends of the stradella keyboard so that you build muscle memory for all left-hand positions.

alternating_bass_4/4_with_double_button.title: Alt. Bass 4/4 w/ Double Button
alternating_bass_4/4_with_double_button.description:
Play a 4/4 Alternating Bass pattern with the addition of hitting both the bass and chord buttons at the end of the bar. Do this in a variety of different keys on both ends of the stradella keyboard so that you build muscle memory for all left-hand positions.

Once comfortable, do this exercise to a metronome.

alternating_bass_6/8.title: Alternating Bass 6/8
alternating_bass_6/8.description:
Practice playing a 6/8 Alternating Bass. Do this in a variety of different keys on both ends of the stradella keyboard so that you build muscle memory for all left-hand positions.

Once comfortable, do this exercise to a metronome.

alternating_bass_1_4_1_5.title: I-IV-I-V Progression
alternating_bass_1_4_1_5.description: Practice playing a I-IV-I-V progression. Do two bars on each chord before moving to the next chord. Repeat.

alternating_bass_6/8_minor.title: Alternating Bass 6/8 Minor
alternating_bass_6/8_minor.description:
Practice playing a 6/8 Alternating Bass using the minor bass buttons.
Once comfortable, move between the I, IV, and V chords.

alternating_bass_4/4_with_counterbass.title: Alternating Bass 4/4
alternating_bass_4/4_with_counterbass.description:
Practice playing a 4/4 Alternating Bass using counterbass button in place of the 5th-base button.
Once comfortable, go back and forth between using the 5th-bass button and the counterbass button. (In other words, do the 5th-bass button on odd bars and the counterbass button on even bars.)

alternating_bass_1_4_5_1.title: i-iv-V7-i Progression
alternating_bass_1_4_5_1.description:
Practice playing a i-iv-V-i progression. Do two bars on each chord before moving to the next chord. Repeat.

Once comfortable, swap the V chord with a V7 chord. (Play the 7th chord button instead of the major chord button.)

alternating_bass_1_5_4_5.title: I-V-IV-V Progression w/ Counterbass
alternating_bass_1_5_4_5.description:
Practice playing a I-V-IV-V progression. Do half a bar on each chord before moving to the next chord. Repeat.

Once comfortable, play the counterbass button instead of the fifth-bass button for the first V chord and for the IV chord.

bass_scales_major.title: Bass Buttons Major Scale
bass_scales_major.description:
Play up the Major Scale until you hit the root note again. Then go back down until you hit the root note. Repeat.

Do this in a variety of different keys on both ends of the stradella keyboard so that you build muscle memory for all left-hand positions.

bass_scales_minor.title: Bass Buttons Minor Scale
bass_scales_minor.description:
Play up the Minor Scale until you hit the root note again. Then go back down until you hit the root note. Repeat.

Do this in two different ways: With the root note on the counterbass row and with the root note on the bass row. And do this in a variety of different keys on both ends of the stradella keyboard so that you build muscle memory for all left-hand positions.

alternating_bass_tin_street_busker.title: Tin Street Busker Progression
alternating_bass_tin_street_busker.description:
Practice playing a I-vi-II-V progression in 6/8. See below for the structure.

Once comfortable, do a more advanced version of the progression: I-vi-II7-V-IV-V. Once again, see below for the structure.

alternating_bass_piano_man.title: Piano Man Chord Progression
alternating_bass_piano_man.description: Practice playing the chord progression from the verse of Piano Man. See below for the structure.

tapping_bass_note.title: Tapping a Bass Note
tapping_bass_note.description:
Tap the C bass note in the left hand while tapping a C note in right-hand simultaneously. Every four taps, switch your right hand note from C to D.

Once comfortable, slowly climb up and down the C major scale on the right hand while tapping the bass note.

back_and_forth_bass_note.title: Back and Forth Bass Note
back_and_forth_bass_note.description:
Alternate between tapping the C bass note in the left hand and tapping a C note in right-hand.

Once comfortable, switch back and forth between this pattern and tapping the two notes simultaneously.

moving_bass_note.title: Moving Bass Note
moving_bass_note.description:
Walk up the E Major Scale on the right hand starting on E and ending on the octave. For the first four notes, tap the E bass button. For the last four notes, tap the B bass button.

Once comfortable, try and variation where you tap E for the first two notes, A for notes 3 and 4, B for notes 5 and 6 and E for notes 7 and 8.

simple_alternating_bass_pattern.title: Simple Alternating Bass Pattern
simple_alternating_bass_pattern.description:
Play a C alternating bass pattern in 4/4 while playing the first three notes of the major scale. C -> D -> E -> D

Once comfortable, try a 6/8 pattern.

mary_had_a_little_lamb_two_handed.title: Mary Had a Little Lamb Two-Hand
mary_had_a_little_lamb_two_handed.description: Play Mary had a Little Lamb with two hands.

major_scale_over_alternating_bass.title: Major Scale over Alternating Bass
major_scale_over_alternating_bass.description:
Play up and down the G Major Scale over a 4/4 alternating bass pattern. Switch between the G chord and the D chord.

Once comfortable, play up the scale in thirds.

major_scale_on_both_hands.title: Major Scale on Both Hands
major_scale_on_both_hands.description: Play up and down the major scale on both hands simultaneously. Once comfortable, also try going up on one hand while going down on the other.

minor_scale_on_both_hands.title: Minor Scale on Both Hands
minor_scale_on_both_hands.description: Play up and down the minor scale on both hands simultaneously. Once comfortable, also try going up on one hand while going down on the other.
